title: 112_hr1903
content: The Act titled "21st Century STEM for Girls and Underrepresented Minorities Act" introduces grants to prepare girls and underrepresented minorities in education. It amends Title V of the Elementary and Secondary Education Act of 1965 to focus on preparing these groups for the 21st century. The Act "21st Century STEM for Girls and Underrepresented Minorities Act" authorizes grants for local educational agencies to establish programs encouraging girls and minorities in STEM fields. Eligible agencies must submit an application to the Secretary for consideration. The application for grants under the "21st Century STEM for Girls and Underrepresented Minorities Act" must include a program description, collaboration between schools, recruitment process, and instructional plans. The grant application must include a program description, collaboration with institutions, and priority given to those with experience in increasing participation of girls and minorities in STEM. Funds will be used for preparing girls and underrepresented minorities in STEM. The grant funds will be used to acquaint and prepare girls and underrepresented minorities for careers in STEM fields, educate parents about opportunities in STEM, enlist parental help in overcoming obstacles, provide tutoring and mentoring programs, and establish partnerships. Establishing partnerships and opportunities to expose girls and underrepresented minorities to role models in STEM fields, enabling them to attend events and academic programs, providing after-school activities, and summer programs to encourage interest and develop skills in science, mathematics, engineering, and technology. The legislation includes provisions for purchasing educational materials and equipment to encourage interest in STEM fields among girls and underrepresented minorities, organizing field trips to institutions of higher education, and providing academic advice and assistance in high school. The legislation also includes provisions for paying internship costs for female and underrepresented minority students in STEM fields, providing professional development for teachers on eliminating gender and racial bias in the classroom, and engaging students in the face of peer pressure and parental expectations. The legislation aims to support girls and underserved minorities in pursuing STEM careers by providing academic advice, creating a positive environment, and not replacing other sources of funding. The evaluation of funds received must be conducted annually by the local educational agency, as prescribed by the Secretary. It should include a description of programs, data on curriculum and partnerships, time spent on grant-allowed subjects, and any other required information. Authorization of appropriations for this part includes $50,000,000 for fiscal year 2012 and necessary sums for the following 4 years.
